title: Disrupting a socio-ecological system: How could traditional ecological knowledge be the key to preserving the Araucaria Forest in Brazil under climate change?
abstract: Abstract Socio-ecological systems (SESs) hinge on human groups and ecosystems, promoting interdependence and resilience to environmental disturbances. Climate change effects propagate from organisms to biomes, likely influencing SESs. In southern Brazil, the Araucaria Forest is a typical SES due to the historical interaction between humans and biodiversity. Thus, we empirically and theoretically evaluated how climate change could disrupt this system by interviewing 97 smallholders and assessing their traditional ecological knowledge (TEK). We evaluated and measured the socioeconomic impact of the araucaria’s ( Araucaria angustifolia ) nut-like seed (pinhão) trade and the ethnoecological knowledge about climate change, as well as generated an ecosystem services network. We used these empirical data with a projected loss of 50–70% of the Araucaria Forest due to climate change to quantify the risks of the potential disruption of this SES. We found evidence that to avoid the disruption of the Araucaria Forests, it is paramount to value TEK holders, safeguard the historical socio-ecological interaction, and promote non-mutually exclusive measures in an integrative response to maintain the resilience of this forest to future disturbances.

motivations: Climate change poses a significant threat to the resilience and stability of socio-ecological systems, including the Araucaria Forest in Brazil.
The loss of traditional ecological knowledge (TEK) could exacerbate the disruption of the Araucaria Forest ecosystem under climate change.
objectives: Evaluate the impact of climate change on the Araucaria Forest socio-ecological system.
Assess the role of traditional ecological knowledge (TEK) in preserving the Araucaria Forest under climate change.
Identify measures to maintain the resilience of the Araucaria Forest ecosystem.
methods: Conduct empirical research through interviews with smallholders to gather data on TEK and socioeconomic impacts.
Assess the ethnoecological knowledge about climate change and generate an ecosystem services network.
Use projected climate change data to quantify the risks of disrupting the Araucaria Forest socio-ecological system.
results: Valuing TEK holders and safeguarding historical socio-ecological interactions are crucial for maintaining the resilience of the Araucaria Forest.
Promoting non-mutually exclusive measures can help mitigate the disruption of the Araucaria Forest ecosystem under climate change.
Integrative responses can support the preservation of the Araucaria Forest and its ecosystem services.
